title: Number of Family Separations at U.S. Border Higher Than Previously Known
summary: ACLU says Trump administration reported more than 1,500 additional children were separated before 'zero tolerance' was fully implemented. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration told the American Civil Liberties Union on Thursday that immigration authorities separated more than 1,500 additional children from their families before its "zero tolerance" policy was fully implemented, bringing the total number of children separated to about 4,300 before a federal judge halted the practice.

title: SoftBank-Backed Car Lessor to Cut 40% of Workforce
summary: Online company Fair announces sweeping layoffs to find path to profitability. Fair, the online car-leasing startup, is the latest company backed by SoftBank Group Corp. to announce sweeping layoffs as it struggles to find a path to profitability.

title: The FCC Chairman on Regulating the Big Tech Companies
summary: Ajit Pai talks about consistent rules and the U.S.-China rivalry over 5G. It is a question that is heating up on the campaign trail and many other venues: Do we need heavier regulations on giant online companies like Facebook , Google and Amazon?

title: U.S. Weighs Leaving More Troops, Sending Battle Tanks to Syria
summary: Options represent a shift from the pullout President Trump wanted and modify U.S. objectives-from countering Islamic State to also protecting oil fields. WASHINGTON-The White House is considering options for leaving about 500 U.S. troops in northeast Syria and for sending dozens of battle tanks and other equipment, officials said Thursday, the latest in an array of scenarios following President Trump's decision this month to remove all troops there.

title: California Blackouts Force Businesses to Tally Their Losses
summary: PG&E's second power shutdown this month raises stakes for stores; utility reports incident on power line near start of Sonoma County fire. The last time PG&E Corp. shut off electricity in the Sierra Nevada foothills city of Placerville, Calif., Pop Art Custom Framing Gallery lost about $8,000 in four days, according to Daniel Anderson, who owns the store with his wife.

title: In a Reversal, Biden Opens Door to Super PAC
summary: The Democratic contender's campaign no longer disavows the idea of an outside group spending money to defend him. WASHINGTON-Joe Biden's campaign cracked open the door Thursday to the possible formation of an independent fundraising group in support of his presidential bid, reversing its stance as Republicans spend millions of dollars against his campaign.

title: U.S. Gives Venezuela's Citgo Temporary Shield From Creditors
summary: Potential seizure of Venezuela's Citgo blocked through Jan. 22. The Trump administration extended a temporary shield over Venezuela's Citgo Petroleum Corp. ahead of a looming debt payment, protecting the Houston-based crude refiner from potential seizure by creditors for three months.

title: Democrats Defend Private Interviews in Impeachment Probe
summary: Lawmakers plan more closed-door depositions as GOP steps up demands for public inquiry. WASHINGTON-House Democrats plan to move ahead with more closed-door interviews in their impeachment inquiry, scheduling current and former White House officials for private depositions next week, but said they hope to hold proceedings in public before Thanksgiving.

title: New Report Evaluates Sanctions Programs in Sub-Saharan Africa
summary: Policy advocacy group says targeted network sanctions are more effective than comprehensive sanctions against an entire country. Sanctions programs levied on some Sub-Saharan African countries could be made more effective by targeting specific networks rather than comprehensive sanctions against an entire country, a new report says.

title: How Bugs Sapped Twitter's Ad Capabilities and Drove Prices Lower
summary: Social-media company had to shut down some targeting and measurement functions. Glitches in Twitter Inc.'s ad-targeting machinery shaved three or more percentage points off the social-media company's sales growth last quarter by limiting the platform's ability to precisely target users and weighing down advertising prices as a result.

title: Bonfire of the Philanthropists
summary: BlackRock's liberal CEO faces political furies he hoped to keep at bay.. The philanthropy that supports America's great cultural institutions is coming into existential conflict with the political climate in the artistic world. Bare-knuckle left-wing activists from groups like "Decolonize This Place" increasingly call the shots, and rich philanthropists, no matter their liberal bona fides, are being stigmatized and banished.

title: Trump's Gift to California
summary: The EPA liberates more water from smelt and salmon regulations.. Amid horrific wildfires and rolling blackouts, the Trump Administration this week brought welcome relief to the Golden State by allowing more water to be sent to farmers and folks in the south. Will California liberals accept the deregulatory gift?

title: Mayor Pete's Supreme Pivot
summary: He speaks well of Justice Anthony Kennedy. Consternation ensues.. South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg didn't register in Democratic presidential polls at the start of this year. Then came his breakthrough: In response to a question in Philadelphia in February, Mr. Buttigieg suggested he was open to packing the U.S. Supreme Court. "In some ways it's no more a shattering of norms than what's already been done to get the judiciary to where it is today," he said.

title: Saudi-Backed Yemeni Government, Separatists Sign Power-Sharing Deal
summary: Agreement aims to keep country from fracturing, facilitate more talks aimed at ending five-year war. The Saudi-backed Yemeni government signed a power-sharing deal with a local group seeking a separate state in the south, an agreement designed to keep the country from fracturing and pave the way for broader talks to end its five-year-old war, people familiar with the talks said.

title: Users Adopt New Tactics to Spread Misleading Information Online
summary: As social-media companies erect barriers, bad actors find ways around them. False and misleading information is spreading in new ways across social media, as people seeking to influence political campaigns or achieve illicit goals attempt to stay ahead of platform operators trying to stop them.

title: China's Efforts to Lead the Way in AI Start in Its Classrooms
summary: A fast-spreading use of artificial intelligence in schools from kindergartens to universities provides the country with an unrivaled database. These days, many students at Jinhua Xiaoshun Primary School in eastern China begin their lessons not by opening textbooks, but by putting on headbands.

title: Amazon's Defense of Private Brands
summary: Jeff Wilke says the company doesn't give its own brand an advantage in its search results. It is tough to be the retail king.

title: Videogames Head for the Clouds
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-Is the videogame console dead?

title: Reimagining the Car and Carbon Removal
summary: Two innovators, Aicha Evans and Anousheh Ansari, talk about their big ideas. What will keep the engine of tech innovation running?

title: Citigroup Puts Jane Fraser in Line to Succeed Corbat as CEO
summary: Bank's Latin America chief tapped as No. 2. Citigroup Inc. tapped its Latin America chief, Jane Fraser, to serve as the bank's No. 2 executive, putting her atop the list to succeed Chief Executive Michael Corbat.

title: Sonoma County Fire Spreads Quickly, Forcing Evacuations
summary: Kincade Fire, fueled by strong winds and dry conditions, threatens wineries and ranches. Close to 2,000 residents of Sonoma County in Northern California have been evacuated as a fire that sparked Wednesday night quickly grew to over 10,000 acres, fueled by strong winds and dry conditions.

title: Amazon's Third-Quarter Profit Slides 26%
summary: Profit slips 26% as company ramps up spending to offer Prime customers one-day deliveries. Amazon.com Inc.'s profit machine sputtered again after more than two years of surging growth, weighed down by the tech giant's heavy investment into reducing shipping times for retail customers.

title: Business Activity Slows Around the World
summary: Interest-rate cuts by leading central banks haven't turned around sluggish economies. Business activity continued to slow around the world headed into the fall, with the U.S. showing signs of tepid growth, an indication that a wave of interest-rate cuts by leading central banks over recent months has yet to turn sluggish economies around.

title: Microsoft Sees Few Clouds on Tech Horizon
summary: Software giant's positive outlook cools fears of a corporate tech meltdown. If there is a broad tech slowdown coming, Microsoft for one isn't seeing it.

title: Visa Reports Better-Than-Expected Revenue
summary: Card network ended the year with $12.08 billion in profit. Higher spending on Visa Inc.'s credit and debit cards drove profit and revenue higher in the latest quarter.

title: Elijah Cummings and the Little Sisters
summary: Beto O'Rourke's punitive position on tax exemptions contrasts with a poignant Capitol Hill memorial.. I was writing a rather stern column about the mess in Washington, but I got kind of swept Thursday by the beautiful bipartisan tribute to Democratic Rep. Elijah Cummings, in Congress's Statuary Hall, a ceremony held just before his burial back in Baltimore.

title: Amazon's Investment Mode Extends
summary: Tech giant's record spending may still result in slower growth. Amazon.com 's giant flywheel is getting harder to turn-or at least more expensive.

title: Astros Fire Assistant General Manager Over Outburst
summary: Brandon Taubman is dismissed after he taunted female reporters during a locker room tirade. The Houston Astros fired assistant general manager Brandon Taubman on Thursday, five days after he profanely taunted a group of female journalists in defense of the team's employment of a pitcher with a domestic violence accusation in his past.

title: CVS to Halt Sales of Some J&J Talcum Powder After Recall
summary: The pharmacy chain recalls 22 oz. bottles of Johnson's Baby Powder after health regulators found asbestos in one bottle. CVS Health Corp. said Thursday it is removing 22 oz. bottles of Johnson's Baby Powder from pharmacy shelves and its online store in response to Johnson & Johnson 's recall of certain bottles last week, after regulators found asbestos in one.

title: Uniroyal CEO Joseph Flannery Won Concessions From Rubber Union
summary: He revived a struggling tire maker and fended off Carl Icahn's hostile takeover bid in the 1980s. Uniroyal Inc., a maker of tires and chemicals, was looking threadbare by the time Joseph Flannery was promoted to chief executive in 1980.

title: CarMax Names New CFO as Part of Succession Plan
summary: Treasurer Enrique Mayor-Mora succeeds Tom Reedy as CFO. CarMax Inc., the U.S.'s largest retailer of used cars, appointed a new finance chief as part of its long-term succession plan.

title: Hong Kong's Revolutionary Turn
summary: Many of the protesters have concluded the 'one country, two systems' model is untenable.. Hong Kong

title: 'What We Did in Bed' Review: How We Hit the Hay
summary: A consideration of the bed-site of countless births, deaths and famous last words-as a prop with which to elaborate upon the "theater of life.". 'The near approach a bed may show / Of human bliss to human woe," mused the 17th-century French poet Isaac de Benserade. In Western households, the bed has traditionally been where most people are conceived and born, convalesce from illness, make love, and die. Upon evolving from straw pallets to wooden frames-complete with mattresses, sheets, blankets and pillows-they served as a center of daytime sociability. Prior to the Industrial Revolution, beds were often a middle-class family's most expensive article of furniture, usually among the first items bequeathed to favored heirs.

title: Why Britain's Divorce From the EU Requires 115 Pages
summary: This is how every effort by a modern state ends up-in endless technocratic and legal mumbo jumbo.. Prime Minister Boris Johnson's bill implementing his Brexit deal is the most controversial piece of British legislation this year, if not this decade. His failure to secure its approval this week imperils both Brexit and Mr. Johnson's government.

title: Behold the Lord High Impeacher
summary: The failure to vote on an inquiry allows Schiff to make up the rules as he goes along.. Rep. Elise Stefanik was informed this week by Republican House Intelligence Committee staffers of a new diktat from Chairman Adam Schiff. It made the New York Republican's jaw drop.

title: College Football as a Religious Experience
summary: 'The moral equivalent of war' played a role in the 1960s civil-rights struggle.. While the National Football League is celebrating its 100th season, college football goes back even further. Originating only four years after the end of the Civil War, the sport kept men from being "soft" and offered what William James deemed "the moral equivalent of war."

title: Blowing the Whistle About a Quid and a Quo
summary: Exchanging one thing for another must be really, really bad.. The dumbest political controversies are the ones in which everybody suddenly uses a term to describe some allegedly bad thing without quite knowing what the term signifies or what the bad thing is. I wish I could forget the idiotic brawl, circa 2007, over whether the Bush administration "cherry-picked" intelligence about Iraq. Isn't every intelligence report, indeed every report, in some sense the product of cherry-picking, since no useful report could include everything there is to know?

title: Citrix Plans to Accelerate Transition to Subscription-Based Model Under New CFO
summary: The software company wants to stop new licenses for one of its products as more customers opt for subscriptions. Citrix Systems Inc.'s new chief financial officer, Arlen Shenkman, faces a challenging task as he aims to advance the software company's transformation to a subscription-based business.

title: Even Experts Are Poorly Informed
summary: If Nate Silver can't grasp the First Amendment, how can anyone be expected to make sense of trade policy?. Political data guru Nate Silver of FiveThirtyEight.com recently tweeted that Mark Zuckerberg's comments about free speech were mistaken because "false statements of fact aren't protected speech in the U.S." That was a false statement-which, fortunately for Mr. Silver the First Amendment does protect. As the saying goes, the remedy for bad speech is more speech.

title: In Defense of iGen
summary: Young people of all generations are prone to embrace simplistic ideologies and forget history.. A student at an academic dinner sent a photo of her entree to her boyfriend in China. A couple of months later he dropped by to visit our class. Twentysomethings have always traveled crazy distances on such adventures, but I've learned it can be just as interesting to send them places locally, then ask what they've discovered. They see things you and I often miss, and they write about them very well. Not all have evident promise, but late bloomers are nothing new.

title: Vale's Third-Quarter Net Income Rises on Higher Production
summary: Lack of new provisions related to dam collapse means investors can start looking closely at Vale's day-to-day business. Brazilian iron-ore miner Vale SA's profit jumped in the third quarter as production increased, prices rose and the financial impact of the deadly dam collapse at Brumadinho waned.

title: Why the 2020 Democratic Polls Are So Different
summary: Some pollsters have repeatedly shown Biden with a wide lead, while others have steadily favored Warren.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Slip
summary: Treasurys give up early gains as investors reassess durable goods data. U.S. government bonds rallied in early trading only to reverse direction late in the session as investors reconsidered data on durable goods sales.

title: 'Synonyms': Exhilarating Words to the Wise
summary: Loathing his homeland, an Israeli ex-soldier moves to Paris to reinvent himself.. One word for Nadav Lapid's "Synonyms," a movie with a hero obsessed with words, is astonishing. Other words apply to this Israeli feature, in subtitled French and Hebrew, that's set in Paris. They include, in no particular order, fascinating, infuriating, frightening, lyrical and befuddling. Plus deadpan funny and frequently stunning as a bittersweet ode to contemporary France, one that's suffused with New Wave verve.

title: 'By the Grace of God': Sinners, Not Saints
summary: Survivors of sexual abuse try to hold a predator priest and the system that protected him to account in François Ozon's powerful film.. What's old heightens the impact of what's new and remarkably timely in François Ozon's powerful "By the Grace of God." In one sense we've been here before. A priest in Lyon, France, is alleged to be a serial pedophile, but the Catholic church hierarchy fights efforts to remove him from the priesthood, let alone bring him to justice. That was the subject area of Amy Berg's 2006 documentary "Deliver Us From Evil," and, of course, of the Oscar-winning "Spotlight," based on a true story, in which journalists, faced with a coverup by the Catholic archdiocese of Boston, found a widespread pattern of pastoral child abuse. Mr. Ozon's film, in subtitled French, closely follows the facts of a pending case that continues to make headlines in France. The church's evasions, obfuscations and rationalizations are shockingly familiar. But the dramatization adds a valuable dimension, vignette by intimate vignette-the terrible toll exacted on victims and their families over the course of decades by a single priest who, early and quite astonishingly in the film, acknowledges his depredations in general terms to one of his victims.

title: 'Fantastic Fungi' Review: Magic Mushrooms
summary: Louie Schwartzberg's documentary is an eloquent paean to an underexplored kingdom.. When a documentary called "Fantastic Fungi" came my way, I met it with modest expectations. As a shiitake mushroom addict, I hoped for good recipes along with edification. In fact, recipes aren't on the menu, and there's too much edification to be digested in one viewing. The film was made by people who want to spread the word about their beloved subject in the overachieving way that fungi spread spores by the billions. But oh, the gorgeous photography! Time-lapse sequences of mushrooms blossoming forth could pass for studies of exotic flowers growing on another planet. (The filmmaker, Louie Schwartzberg, has long been a time-lapse specialist.) The narrator, Brie Larson, clearly had fun with the highfalutin introduction. How often can a Hollywood star speak for all the fungi of our planet and say things like "We are the wisdom of a billion years, we are creation, we are resurrection, condemnation and regeneration-we...are...mushrooms"? Once you see what she's talking about, though, you'll believe anything she says.

title: UAW Members Are Tilting in Favor of New Contract With GM
summary: A majority of GM factory workers casting ballots so far are voting to back the proposed four-year deal. Unionized workers at several major General Motors Co. factories have voted to back a proposed labor contract, an encouraging sign for United Auto Workers leaders under pressure to get a deal approved and end a six-week nationwide strike.

title: Intel Raises Outlook, Sending Shares Higher
summary: Chip maker posts higher profit and sales for latest period; stock jumps in after-market trading. Intel Corp. reported stronger third-quarter earnings and again raised its full-year outlook, helping ease investor concerns about production bottlenecks at the chip maker and a broader slowdown in demand.

title: U.K.'s Johnson Calls for Election in Bid to Advance Brexit
summary: Leader, trying to push Brexit forward in Parliament, would need opposition support for a vote to take place. LONDON-U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson called for a snap general election on Dec. 12 in an effort to pressure his political opponents to back his Brexit deal and face him at the ballot box, but opposition lawmakers suggested they wouldn't rise to the bait.

title: Wall Street Is Once Again Chummy With PayPal
summary: The payments company is back in investors' good graces as growth picks up. The intermission is over for PayPal Holdings .

title: S&P 500 Inches Up as Investors Focus on Earnings
summary: Twitter shares drop as quarterly results disappoint; Tesla surges. The S&P 500 edged higher Thursday, as investors contended with a mixed bag of corporate profit reports that offered a murky outlook on the state of the U.S. economy.

title: PayPal's Results Put Charge in Share Price
summary: An increase in user base eases investors' concerns about financial-tech company's trajectory. Shares in PayPal Holdings Inc. rose nearly 9% on Thursday, their biggest one-day gain in over a year, after the financial-tech company reported a jump in its user base and progress in making money from its Venmo service.

title: Home-Improvement Boom Is Forecast to Fizzle
summary: Renovation and maintenance spending-a barometer of the housing market-are expected to decline for the first time in a decade. Home-improvement retailers have proven a bright spot during an otherwise underwhelming stretch for retail stocks, but a popular predictor of remodeling spending suggests tougher times ahead.

title: Tesla Turns a Corner. It May Not Be the Last One.
summary: The company's shares jumped Thursday after its latest earnings report. It looks like Elon Musk has finally steered Tesla Inc. around the proverbial corner. The question now is how many more he'll have to navigate.

title: 'Mrs. Fletcher': A Late-in-Life Awakening
summary: Kathryn Hahn stars as a divorced single mother in her 40s who discovers the pleasures of her own life after her son goes to college.. While providing fans of Kathryn Hahn hours of delirium, the seven-part "Mrs. Fletcher" is a bold, engaging, sexy coming-of-age story that may well prompt viewers to ask: What age? The puzzlement isn't about the birthdate of Eve Fletcher, though she is a bit older than your standard-issue naif of fiction. It's more about the fact that she's an extremely attractive, intelligent, divorced single mother in her 40s who lives in the real world, suffers no apparent cognitive impairment, runs an assisted-living facility for seniors and yet seems to have had her soul and libido bubble-wrapped sometime circa Henrik Ibsen.

title: 'Rothko: Pictures Must Be Miraculous' Review: An Intelligent Portrait
summary: Despite too much focus on the artist's market success, this 'American Masters' entry reveals Mark Rothko's true genius.. There's something unintentionally perverse about the setup of "Rothko: Pictures Must Be Miraculous," the what-were-they-waiting-for "American Masters" entry on Mark Rothko. The opening scenes date to 2012 at Christie's in New York, where a Rothko was setting the then-record price for a postwar panting at auction

title: Twitter Shares Fall as Ad-Business Woes Weigh on Growth
summary: Tepid outlook shaves off a fifth of the social-media company's stock market value, prompts questions. Technical glitches in Twitter Inc.'s advertising software roiled the social-media company in the third quarter, as a pullback in spending from some buyers and weaker pricing for ads also cut into revenue and profit even though it added millions of new users.

title: American, Southwest Under Pressure From 737 MAX Grounding
summary: Both airlines say strong demand for travel helped boost quarterly revenue, even though they have had to curtail growth plans. Airlines are ramping up pressure on Boeing Co. to help compensate them for lost revenue and higher costs as the grounding of the plane maker's 737 MAX aircraft stretches into its eighth month.

title: Finra Fines BNP Paribas $15 Million Over Money-Laundering Controls
summary: Says BNP lacked program that could detect suspicious activity in penny stocks, wire transfers. The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said Thursday it fined BNP Paribas SA $15 million for failing to develop an anti-money-laundering program that could detect suspicious penny stock and wire transfer activity.

title: Trump to Order Federal Agencies to Cut Times, Post Subscriptions
summary: White House plans to direct government staffers to not renew orders with the newspapers, whose coverage he has disparaged as 'fake'. WASHINGTON-The White House is planning to instruct federal agencies to not renew their subscriptions to the New York Times and the Washington Post, administration officials said, escalating President Trump's attacks on the media outlets.

title: Hunter Biden Worldwide
summary: Have you heard about his work in Romania?. Should Washington have done more to encourage foreign governments to examine the business activities of Hunter Biden? Hanging out the Biden shingle in jurisdictions where Barack Obama's vice president was leading U.S. policy appears to have been a more lucrative enterprise than previously believed.

title: Kate Moss's Vintage-Fashion Obsessions
summary: The model and antique-clothing collector teamed up with Chile's Museo de la Moda on a book highlighting 100 of its pieces that echo her own vintage fascinations. Here, 5 key themes unpacked. Early 20th-century designers Paul Poiret and Jeanne Lanvin popularized opera coats in opulent materials like velvet, brocade, fur and gold braid. Part cocoon, part butterfly, an opera coat is "the perfect finish to an evening look," Ms. Moss writes in 'Musings on Fashion & Style.' But she has been known to wear the coats in broad daylight, too, as in the iconic 1998 Juergen Teller photograph above. The museum's collection features a similar 1925 Lanvin-Fourrures piece in silk velvet and otter fur, pictured.

title: Balkanization of Language Inhibits Debate
summary: President Trump used the same word that Sens. Joe Biden and John Kerry used in response to the President Bill Clinton impeachment. Where was the press outrage then?. Regarding your editorial "Donald Trump's 'Lynching'" (Oct. 23): President Trump used the same word that Sens. Joe Biden and John Kerry used in response to the President Bill Clinton impeachment. Where was the press outrage then?

title: European Rights Award Goes to Jailed Uighur Activist
summary: Award for Ilham Tohti puts EU stamp on criticism of Beijing's campaign against Muslim minority. BRUSSELS-Jailed Uighur activist Ilham Tohti was awarded the European Parliament's annual human-rights prize on Thursday, a signal of growing concern in Western countries about China's treatment of the mainly Muslim minority group.

title: Two Ways of Looking at Government Policy
summary: "Orwell's novel ["1984"] remains the book we turn to when truth is mutilated, language distorted, power abused-and we want to know how bad things can get.". A comparison of book reviews by Barton Swaim and Michael O'Donnell (Books, Oct. 19) reveals surprising similarities. Mr. Swaim critiques two books by Obama-administration apologists: Samantha Power's "The Education of an Idealist" and Susan Rice's "Tough Love," while Mr. O'Donnell looks at two books exploring George Orwell's intentions in writing his iconic "Nineteen Eighty-Four": Dorian Lynskey's "The Ministry of Truth" and D.J. Taylor's "On Nineteen Eighty-Four." One year after President Obama's infamous "red line" statement, Ms. Power, as ambassador to the U.N., explained away his lack of response to Syria's use of chemical weapons not as the worst foreign-policy blunder, but as a success when Bashar al-Assad surrendered "a whopping 1,300 tons of chemical agents," but not all his stockpile, some of which he used four years later. Similarly, Ms. Rice attempts to explain away her Sunday morning newsfest that the attack on the American consulate in Benghazi was based on a flawed early assessment by the intelligence community.

title: Barneys Moves Forward on Sale to Authentic Brands Group
summary: Rival bidder, meanwhile, still working on an offer that would keep stores open. Barneys New York Inc. is moving forward with the sale of its brand and assets to a licensing company, but the bankrupt retailer hasn't completely shut the door on a rival bidder that would keep its stores open.

title: The Fall of WeWork: How a Startup Darling Came Unglued
summary: Resume Subscription. Just months before the spectacular fall of WeWork, one of the country's most gilded startups, chief executive Adam Neumann summoned the heads of the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq to one of his homes in the Hamptons.

title: Lawmakers Push to Pass Revised Trade Deal as Year's End Approaches
summary: Democrats seek agreement on changes to the USMCA before 2020 election clouds prospects for passage. WASHINGTON-Lawmakers worry that the window to pass the Trump administration's renegotiated trade deal with Mexico and Canada is closing, and if negotiations don't conclude soon, the pact's prospects could fade against political priorities in the coming election year.

title: Many Workers Paid a Price for UAW's Strike
summary: While GM workers will go back to work with a healthy increase, the Tier employees who do go back to their jobs will simply be able to go back to work with accrued lost wages and benefits incurred during the layoffs.. Regarding your editorial "The Price of the Union at GM" (Oct. 19): For every GM employee at an assembly plant, there are at least 30 working at suppliers providing parts, materials and services to those plants. These are known as Tier 1, 2 and 3 suppliers. Tier 1s supply directly to the OEM, Tier 2s to the Tier 1s, etc.

title: California Drives the Rich Away, Reduces Inequality
summary: Your editorial, "California's Tax-the-Rich Boomerang" (Oct. 22) reports a study that "estimates that outward migration and taxpayer behavioral responses erased 45.2% of the expected revenue gains from the tax hike on top earners.". Your editorial "California's Tax-the-Rich Boomerang" (Oct. 22) reports a study that "estimates that outward migration and taxpayer behavioral responses erased 45.2% of the expected revenue gains from the tax hike on top earners." By the Journal's standards, that is a failure. By progressive standards, perhaps not. Chasing out the high earners does, after all, reduce inequality.

title: Magical Experiences Then Were Different Than Now
summary: Driving cross country as a 19-year-old in a beat-up car with only $50 cash and a gas-station map without Interstates was a magical experience.. In "How Steam and Chips Remade the World" (op-ed, Oct. 19), John Steele Gordon remarks that "a man from half a century ago would surely regard the . . . smartphone as magic." As one of those men, who keeps his phone more off than on, I disagree. Driving cross country as a 19-year-old in a beat-up car with only $50 cash and a gas-station map, without interstates, was a magical experience. Magic today would be a young person doing the same, or finding a parent who would let them.

title: VA Investigators Fault Whistleblower Office Created by Trump
summary: Body to protect employees exposing wrongdoing instead retaliated against them, watchdog says. An office formed by President Trump to protect whistleblowers in the Department of Veterans Affairs was instead used to stifle claims and retaliate against those trying to expose problems at the agency, according to an inspector general report released Thursday.

title: Natural-Gas Prices Rise on Cooler-Weather Expectations
summary: Demand for natural gas tends to climb when people use their heaters. The price of natural gas posted a third consecutive session of gains on Thursday, buoyed by expectations for cooler-than-usual fall weather in some parts of the country.

title: Once Asking $250 Million, America's Onetime Priciest Home Sells for Less
summary: It went on the market three years ago with a candy room, a crocodile skin-clad elevator and a hefty price tag. Now Bruce Makowsky's home has sold for $94 million.. After nearly three years on the market, America's most expensive home has finally sold-for 62% off.

title: Amgen to Sell Cholesterol Drug for 60% Less Than Original Price
summary: Repatha's initial price of more than $14,000 a year has been a deterrent to sales. Amgen Inc. said it will sell the cholesterol drug Repatha only at a list price 60% lower than what the company had originally charged, in a bid to make the medicine more affordable to patients and kick-start sales.

title: An Over-the-Top Mansion Built for a Billionaire
summary: Once America's most expensive home, this massive Los Angeles spec house developed by Bruce Makowsky packs in a candy room, a James Bond-inspired movie theater and a bowling alley.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: 'Soft Power' Review: Singing China's Praises
summary: The new David Henry Hwang-Jeanine Tesori musical tackles cultural diplomacy in the age of Trump in a smart and touching fashion.. New York

title: 'Molly Sweeney' Review: An Eye-Opening Experience
summary: In Brian Friel's play, a blind woman has her sight restored by surgery, only to see that her life and relationships aren't what they once seemed..

title: Investors Are Too Fashion-Forward At Gucci
summary: Brand's parent, Kering, has an unflattering stock market valuation, despite strong quarterly sales growth. Luxury investors need to be sensitive to the whims of fashion, but they have been too quick to predict Gucci's demise.

title: Gucci Sales Growth Slows, Hurt by Hong Kong Turmoil
summary: Results at Italian fashion house still beat analysts' expectations. PARIS-Sales growth at Gucci slowed to its lowest level in more than three years, as protests in Hong Kong and the aftermath of the brand's blackface scandal took their toll on the Italian fashion house.

title: When Will the Democratic Presidential Primary Finally Slim Down?
summary: The unusually large field has already shed about a quarter of its contenders, but 17 remain active.

title: Democrats Defend Private Interviews in Impeachment Probe
summary: Lawmakers plan more closed-door depositions as GOP lawmakers step up demands for public inquiry.

title: The New Generation of 'Classic Cars' Comes From the '90s
summary: With a boost from their appearance in 'The Fast and the Furious' movie franchise, sporty cars like these have become newly collectible. HI, I'M DAN, and I'm a gearhead...Hi, Dan.... So, I haven't bought a classic car in nine years...Whoo hoo, keep coming back!... but lately I've been thinking I could handle it again. Uncomfortable silence...I know, I know! I don't have the time, the money, the tools, even a garage or driveway. I mean, I'd be swapping out brake pads and gearboxes in the street. Denial isn't just a river in Egypt.

title: Russia Strikes Rebel Stronghold in Northwest Syria
summary: Airstrikes come following a Moscow-brokered border deal with Turkey in northeastern Syria. Russian aircraft carried out strikes on the last rebel stronghold in northwestern Syria early Thursday, according to a monitoring group and rescue workers, raising fears of an all-out Syrian regime offensive to retake the area following a Moscow-brokered border deal with Turkey.

title: Why the U.K. Isn't Having Problems With Vaping
summary: The lessons of Prohibition's failure in the U.S. haven't been lost on the British.. The Volstead Act prohibiting intoxicating beverages became law on October 28, 1919-a century ago this week-and came into force a few months later. Most people now agree that Prohibition was a failure, driving the alcohol industry underground, where its products became unsafe, its profits lucrative and tax-free, and its methods violent. Most countries have since taken the view that it is better to legalize, regulate and tax drink than to ban it.

title: The 5 Wines We Should Be Drinking More Of
summary: Some wines simply don't get the attention and respect they deserve. Our wine columnist's top 5 underrated bottles are overachievers when it comes to quality, quaffability and value for money. Although Alsace produces some of the most interesting white wines made in France, they've never been a particularly easy sell in the U.S. For one, they tend to come in tall, slender, Germanic-looking bottles, which only confuses matters. Though Alsace belonged to Germany from 1871 to 1918, its Rieslings have a style distinct from that of the German Rieslings associated with that bottle shape. Some fault, too, lies with the producers, who don't seem to focus overmuch on making their wines better understood by Americans. And the way the wines are categorized and sold here certainly doesn't help. When I went looking for Rieslings from Alsace in my local wine shop, I found them grouped under "dessert wines." Never mind that nearly all the wines displayed were actually dry.

title: David Lynch Doesn't Believe in Suffering for Art
summary: "I don't believe that van Gogh, for instance, was suffering while he was painting. Because he loved to paint." The 'Twin Peaks' and 'Blue Velvet' director discusses his own exhibition of paintings. To raise money for his 1977 feature film, Eraserhead, David Lynch once had a job delivering The Wall Street Journal in Los Angeles. "I had a night route-picked up my papers at 11:30 p.m., and I had it down to one hour flat. I made $50 dollars a week," he recalls over the phone. For Lynch, the director behind films such as Blue Velvet and Mulholland Drive and the television series Twin Peaks, it was one of the more unusual posts he held over the course of his six-decade career as an artist and filmmaker.
